\vldbTitle

Privacy Preserving Vertical Federated Learning for Tree-based Models \vldbAuthorsYuncheng Wu, Shaofeng Cai, Xiaokui Xiao, Gang Chen, Beng Chin Ooi \vldbDOIhttps://doi.org/10.14778/3407790.3407811 \vldbVolume13 \vldbNumber11 \vldbYear2020

Privacy Preserving Vertical Federated Learning for Tree-based Models
[Technical Report]

Yuncheng Wu†, Shaofeng Cai†, Xiaokui Xiao†, Gang Chen‡, Beng Chin Ooi†
†National University of Singapore ‡Zhejiang University                 
          {wuyc    shaofeng    xiaoxk    ooibc}@comp.nus.edu.sg cg@zju.edu.cn
Abstract

Federated learning (FL) is an emerging paradigm that enables multiple organizations to jointly train a model without revealing their private data to each other. This paper studies vertical federated learning, which tackles the scenarios where (i) collaborating organizations own data of the same set of users but with disjoint features, and (ii) only one organization holds the labels. We propose Pivot, a novel solution for privacy preserving vertical decision tree training and prediction, ensuring that no intermediate information is disclosed other than those the clients have agreed to release (i.e., the final tree model and the prediction output). Pivot does not rely on any trusted third party and provides protection against a semi-honest adversary that may compromise m−1𝑚1m-1 out of m𝑚m clients. We further identify two privacy leakages when the trained decision tree model is released in plaintext and propose an enhanced protocol to mitigate them. The proposed solution can also be extended to tree ensemble models, e.g., random forest (RF) and gradient boosting decision tree (GBDT) by treating single decision trees as building blocks. Theoretical and experimental analysis suggest that Pivot is efficient for the privacy achieved.

1 Introduction

There has been a growing interest in exploiting data from distributed databases of multiple organizations, for providing better customer service and acquisition. Federated learning (FL) [52, 53] (or collaborative learning [43]) is an emerging paradigm for machine learning that enables multiple data owners (i.e., clients) to jointly train a model without revealing their private data to each other. The basic idea of FL is to iteratively let each client (i) perform some local computations on her data to derive certain intermediate results, and then (ii) exchange these results with other clients in a secure manner to advance the training process, until a final model is obtained. The advantage of FL is that it helps each client protect her data assets, so as to abide by privacy regulations (e.g., GDPR [3] and CCPA [1]) or to maintain a competitive advantage from proprietary data.

Existing work on FL has mainly focused on the horizontal setting [9, 52, 53, 81, 66, 60, 8, 59, 55], which assumes that each client’s data have the same schema, but no tuple is shared by multiple clients. In practice, however, there is often a need for vertical federated learning, where all clients hold the same set of records, while each client only has a disjoint subset of features. For example, Figure 1 illustrates a digital banking scenario, where a bank and a Fintech company aim to jointly build a machine learning model that evaluates credit card applications. The bank has some partial information about the users (e.g., account balances), while the Fintech company has some other information (e.g., the users’ online transactions). In this scenario, vertical FL could enable the bank to derive a more accurate model, while the Fintech company could benefit from a pay-per-use model [73] for its contribution to the training and prediction.

To our knowledge, there exist only a few solutions [71, 44, 67, 68, 69, 21, 50, 60] for privacy preserving vertical FL. These solutions, however, are insufficient in terms of either efficiency or data privacy. In particular, [71, 44] assume that the labels in the training data could be shared with all participating clients in plaintext, whereas in practice, the labels often exist in one client’s data only and could not be revealed to other clients without violating privacy. For instance, in the scenario illustrated in Figure 1, the training data could be a set of historical credit card applications, and each label would be a ground truth that indicates whether the application should have been approved. In this case, the labels are only available to the bank and could not be directly shared with the Fintech company. As a consequence, the solutions in [71, 44] are inapplicable. Meanwhile, [67, 68, 69, 21, 50] assume that some intermediate results during the execution could be revealed in plaintext; nevertheless, such intermediate results could be exploited by an adversarial client to infer the sensitive information in other clients’ data. The solution in [60], on the other hand, relies on secure hardware [51] for privacy protection, but such secure hardware may not be trusted by all parties [81] and could be vulnerable to side channel attacks [76]. The method in [57] utilizes secure multiparty computation (MPC) [78], but assumes that each client’s data could be outsourced to a number of non-colluding servers. This assumption is rather strong, as it is often challenging in practice to ensure that those servers do not collude and to convince all clients about it.

To address the above issues, we propose Pivot, a novel and efficient solution for vertical FL that does not rely on any trusted third party and provides protection against a semi-honest adversary that may compromise m−1𝑚1m-1 out of m𝑚m clients. Pivot is a part of our Falcon111https://www.comp.nus.edu.sg/~dbsystem/fintech/project/falcon/ (federated learning with privacy protection) system, and it ensures that no intermediate information is disclosed during the training or prediction process. Specifically, Pivot is designed for training decision tree (DT) models, which are well adopted for financial risk management [21, 50], healthcare analytics [6], and fraud detection [16] due to their good interpretability. The core of Pivot is a hybrid framework that utilizes both threshold partially homomorphic encryption (TPHE) and MPC, which are two cryptographic techniques that complement each other especially in the vertical FL setting: TPHE is relatively efficient in terms of communication cost but can only support a restrictive set of computations, whereas MPC could support an arbitrary computation but incurs expensive communication overheads. Pivot employs TPHE as much as possible to facilitate clients’ local computation, and only invokes MPC in places where TPHE is inadequate in terms of functionality. This leads to a solution that is not only secure but also highly efficient for vertical tree models, as demonstrated in Section 8. Specifically, we make the following contributions:

  • •

    We propose a basic protocol of Pivot that supports the training of both classification trees and regression trees, as well as distributed prediction using the tree models obtained. This basic protocol guarantees that each client only learns the final tree model but nothing else. To our knowledge, Pivot is the first vertical FL solution that achieves such a guarantee.

  • •

    We enhance the basic protocol of Pivot to handle a more stringent case where parts of the final tree model need to be concealed for better privacy protection. In addition, we propose extensions of Pivot for training several ensemble tree-based models, including random forest (RF) and gradient boosting decision trees (GBDT).

  • •

    We implement DT, RF, and GBDT models based on Pivot and conduct extensive evaluations on both real and synthetic datasets. The results demonstrate that Pivot offers accuracy comparable to non-private algorithms and provides high efficiency. The basic and enhanced protocols of Pivot achieve up to 37.5x and 4.5x speedup (w.r.t. training time) over an MPC baseline.

2 Preliminaries

2.1 Partially Homomorphic Encryption

A partially homomorphic encryption (PHE) scheme is a probabilistic asymmetric encryption scheme for restricted computation over the ciphertexts. In this paper, we utilize the Paillier cryptosystem [61], which consists of three algorithms (Gen, Enc, Dec):

  • •

    The key generation algorithm (s​k,p​k)=Gen​(k​e​y​s​i​z​e)𝑠𝑘𝑝𝑘Gen𝑘𝑒𝑦𝑠𝑖𝑧𝑒(sk,pk)=\textbf{Gen}(keysize) which returns secret key s​k𝑠𝑘sk and public key p​k𝑝𝑘pk, given a security parameter keysize.

  • •

    The encryption algorithm c=Enc​(x,p​k)𝑐Enc𝑥𝑝𝑘c=\textbf{Enc}(x,pk), which maps a plaintext x𝑥x to a ciphertext c𝑐c using p​k𝑝𝑘pk.

  • •

    The decryption algorithm x=Dec​(c,s​k)𝑥Dec𝑐𝑠𝑘x=\textbf{Dec}(c,sk), which reverses the encryption by s​k𝑠𝑘sk and outputs the plaintext x𝑥x.

Interested readers are referred to [27] for the exact construction of Enc and Dec. For simplicity, we omit the public key p​k𝑝𝑘pk in the Enc algorithm and write Enc​(x)Enc𝑥\textbf{Enc}(x) as [x]delimited-[]𝑥[x] in the rest of the paper. =[𝒙⋅𝒗]absentdelimited-[]⋅𝒙𝒗\displaystyle=[\boldsymbol{x}\cdot\boldsymbol{v}]

We utilize a threshold variant of the PHE scheme (i.e., TPHE) with the following additional properties. First, the public key p​k𝑝𝑘pk is known to everyone, while each client only holds a partial secret key. Second, the decryption of a ciphertext requires inputs from a certain number of clients. In this paper, we use a full threshold structure, which requires all clients to participate in order to decrypt a ciphertext.

2.2 Secure Multiparty Computation

Secure multiparty computation (MPC) allows participants to compute a function over their inputs while keeping the inputs private. In this paper, we utilize the additive secret sharing scheme SPDZ [28] for MPC. We refer to a value a∈ℤq𝑎subscriptℤ𝑞a\in\mathbb{Z}_{q} that is additively shared among clients as a secretly shared value, and denote it as ⟨a⟩=(⟨a⟩1,⋯,⟨a⟩m)delimited-⟨⟩𝑎subscriptdelimited-⟨⟩𝑎1⋯subscriptdelimited-⟨⟩𝑎𝑚\langle a\rangle=({\langle a\rangle}_{1},\cdots,{\langle a\rangle}_{m}), where ⟨a⟩isubscriptdelimited-⟨⟩𝑎𝑖{\langle a\rangle}_{i} is a random share of ⟨a⟩delimited-⟨⟩𝑎\langle a\rangle hold by client i𝑖i. To reconstruct a secretly shared value ⟨a⟩delimited-⟨⟩𝑎\langle a\rangle, i.e., Rec​(⟨a⟩)Recdelimited-⟨⟩𝑎\textbf{Rec}(\langle a\rangle), every client can send its own share to a specific client who computes a=(∑i=1m⟨a⟩i)modq𝑎modulosuperscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑚subscriptdelimited-⟨⟩𝑎𝑖𝑞a=(\sum_{i=1}^{m}{\langle a\rangle}_{i})\mod q. Given secretly shared values, we have the following secure computation primitives. For ease of exposition, we omit the modular operation in the following formulations.

Secure addition: given two secretly shared values ⟨a⟩delimited-⟨⟩𝑎\langle a\rangle and ⟨b⟩delimited-⟨⟩𝑏\langle b\rangle, the secretly shared sum c=a+b𝑐𝑎𝑏c=a+b can be obtained by having client i𝑖i non-interactively compute ⟨c⟩i=⟨a⟩i+⟨b⟩isubscriptdelimited-⟨⟩𝑐𝑖subscriptdelimited-⟨⟩𝑎𝑖subscriptdelimited-⟨⟩𝑏𝑖{\langle c\rangle}_{i}={\langle a\rangle}_{i}+{\langle b\rangle}_{i}. Then ⟨c⟩isubscriptdelimited-⟨⟩𝑐𝑖{\langle c\rangle}_{i} is a share of ⟨c⟩delimited-⟨⟩𝑐\langle c\rangle owned by client i𝑖i.

Secure multiplication: given two secretly shared values ⟨a⟩delimited-⟨⟩𝑎\langle a\rangle and ⟨b⟩delimited-⟨⟩𝑏\langle b\rangle, the secretly shared multiplication c=a⋅b𝑐⋅𝑎𝑏c=a\cdot b can be obtained using Beaver’s pre-computed multiplication triplet technique [7]. Assuming that the clients have already shared ⟨u⟩delimited-⟨⟩𝑢\langle u\rangle, ⟨v⟩delimited-⟨⟩𝑣\langle v\rangle, ⟨z⟩delimited-⟨⟩𝑧\langle z\rangle where u,v𝑢𝑣u,v are random values in ℤqsubscriptℤ𝑞\mathbb{Z}_{q} and z=u⋅vmodq𝑧modulo⋅𝑢𝑣𝑞z=u\cdot v\mod q, then client i𝑖i locally computes ⟨e⟩i=⟨a⟩i−⟨u⟩isubscriptdelimited-⟨⟩𝑒𝑖subscriptdelimited-⟨⟩𝑎𝑖subscriptdelimited-⟨⟩𝑢𝑖{\langle e\rangle}_{i}={\langle a\rangle}_{i}-{\langle u\rangle}_{i} and ⟨f⟩i=⟨b⟩i−⟨v⟩isubscriptdelimited-⟨⟩𝑓𝑖subscriptdelimited-⟨⟩𝑏𝑖subscriptdelimited-⟨⟩𝑣𝑖{\langle f\rangle}_{i}={\langle b\rangle}_{i}-{\langle v\rangle}_{i}, and the clients run Rec​(⟨e⟩)Recdelimited-⟨⟩𝑒\textbf{Rec}(\langle e\rangle) and Rec​(⟨f⟩)Recdelimited-⟨⟩𝑓\textbf{Rec}(\langle f\rangle). Finally, every client i𝑖i computes ⟨c⟩i=−i⋅e⋅f+f⋅⟨a⟩i+e⋅⟨b⟩i+⟨z⟩isubscriptdelimited-⟨⟩𝑐𝑖⋅𝑖𝑒𝑓⋅𝑓subscriptdelimited-⟨⟩𝑎𝑖⋅𝑒subscriptdelimited-⟨⟩𝑏𝑖subscriptdelimited-⟨⟩𝑧𝑖{\langle c\rangle}_{i}=-i\cdot e\cdot f+f\cdot{\langle a\rangle}_{i}+e\cdot{\langle b\rangle}_{i}+{\langle z\rangle}_{i}. Then ⟨c⟩isubscriptdelimited-⟨⟩𝑐𝑖{\langle c\rangle}_{i} is a share of ⟨c⟩delimited-⟨⟩𝑐\langle c\rangle owned by client i𝑖i.

Secure comparison: given two shared values ⟨a⟩delimited-⟨⟩𝑎\langle a\rangle and ⟨b⟩delimited-⟨⟩𝑏\langle b\rangle, the secure comparison operation (e.g., ⟨a⟩>⟨b⟩delimited-⟨⟩𝑎delimited-⟨⟩𝑏\langle a\rangle>\langle b\rangle) returns a secretly shared ⟨0⟩delimited-⟨⟩0\langle 0\rangle or ⟨1⟩delimited-⟨⟩1\langle 1\rangle. The basic idea is to first truncate the two values by 2ksuperscript2𝑘2^{k}, then execute ⟨a⟩−⟨b⟩delimited-⟨⟩𝑎delimited-⟨⟩𝑏\langle a\rangle-\langle b\rangle, and finally output the secretly shared sign bit after dividing by 2k−1superscript2𝑘12^{k-1}. We refer the interested readers to [17, 18] for details.

Based on the above primitives, other primitives including secure division and secure exponential can be approximated, which are also supported in SPDZ [18, 28, 5]. In this paper, we use these secure computations in SPDZ as building blocks by default for the calculation concerning secretly shared values, which means that the outputs are also secretly shared values unless they are reconstructed. The secret sharing based MPC has two phases: an offline phase that is independent of the function and generates pre-computed Beaver’s triplets, and an online phase that computes the designated function using these triplets.

2.3 Tree-based Models

In this paper, we consider the classification and regression trees (CART) algorithm [13] with binary structure, while we note that other variants (e.g., ID3 [64], C4.5 [65]) can be easily generalized. We assume there is a training dataset D𝐷{D} with n𝑛n data points {x1,⋯,xn}subscriptx1⋯subscriptx𝑛\{\textbf{x}_{1},\cdots,\textbf{x}_{n}\} each containing d𝑑d features and the corresponding output label set Y={y1,⋯,yn}𝑌subscript𝑦1⋯subscript𝑦𝑛Y=\{y_{1},\cdots,y_{n}\}.

Algorithm 1 describes the CART algorithm, which builds a tree recursively. For each tree node, it first decides whether some pruning conditions are satisfied, e.g., feature set is empty, tree reaches the maximum depth, the number of samples is less than a threshold. If any condition is satisfied, then it returns a leaf node with the class of majority samples for classification or the mean label value for regression. Otherwise, it determines the best split to construct two sub-trees that are built recursively. In order to find the best split feature and split threshold, CART uses Gini impurity [13] as a metric in classification. Let c𝑐c be the number of classes and K={1,⋯,c}𝐾1⋯𝑐K=\{1,\cdots,c\} be the class set. Let D𝐷D be sample set on a given node, the Gini impurity is:

IG​(D)=1−∑k∈K(pk)2subscript𝐼𝐺𝐷1subscript𝑘𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑘2\displaystyle I_{G}(D)=1-\sum\nolimits_{k\in K}(p_{k})^{2} (4)

where pksubscript𝑝𝑘p_{k} is the fraction of samples in D𝐷D labeled with class k𝑘k. Let F𝐹F be the set of available features, given any split feature j∈F𝑗𝐹j\in F and split value τ∈Domain​(j)𝜏Domain𝑗\tau\in\text{Domain}(j), the sample set D𝐷D can be split into two partitions Dlsubscript𝐷𝑙D_{l} and Drsubscript𝐷𝑟D_{r}. Then, the impurity gain of this split is as follows:

=wl​∑k∈K(pl,k)2+wr​∑k∈K(pr,k)2−∑k∈K(pk)2absentsubscript𝑤𝑙subscript𝑘𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑙𝑘2subscript𝑤𝑟subscript𝑘𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑟𝑘2subscript𝑘𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑘2\displaystyle=w_{l}\sum\nolimits_{k\in K}(p_{l,k})^{2}+w_{r}\sum\nolimits_{k\in K}(p_{r,k})^{2}-\sum\nolimits_{k\in K}(p_{k})^{2} (5)

where wl=|Dl|/|D|subscript𝑤𝑙subscript𝐷𝑙𝐷w_{l}=|D_{l}|/|D| and wr=|Dr|/|D|subscript𝑤𝑟subscript𝐷𝑟𝐷w_{r}=|D_{r}|/|D|, and pl,ksubscript𝑝𝑙𝑘p_{l,k} (resp. pr,ksubscript𝑝𝑟𝑘p_{r,k}) is the fraction of samples in Dlsubscript𝐷𝑙D_{l} (resp. Drsubscript𝐷𝑟D_{r}) that are labeled with class k∈K𝑘𝐾k\in K. The split with the maximum impurity gain is considered the best split of the node. For regression, CART uses the label variance as a metric. Let Y𝑌Y be the set of labels of D𝐷D, then the label variance is:

IV​(D)=E​(Y2)−(E​(Y))2=1n​∑i=1nyi2−(1n​∑i=1nyi)2subscript𝐼𝑉𝐷𝐸superscript𝑌2superscript𝐸𝑌21𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑦𝑖2superscript1𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝑦𝑖2\displaystyle I_{V}(D)=E(Y^{2})-(E(Y))^{2}=\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}y_{i}^{2}-(\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}y_{i})^{2} (6)

Similar to Eqn (2.3), the best split is determined by maximizing the variance gain. With CART, ensemble models can be trained to obtain better predictive performance, such as random forest (RF) [12], gradient boosting decision tree (GBDT) [35, 36], XGBoost [20], etc.

3 Solution Overview

3.1 System Model

We consider a set of m𝑚m distributed clients (or data owners) {u1,⋯,um}subscript𝑢1⋯subscript𝑢𝑚\{u_{1},\cdots,u_{m}\} who want to train a decision tree model by consolidating their respective dataset {D1,⋯,Dm}subscript𝐷1⋯subscript𝐷𝑚\{{D}_{1},\cdots,{D}_{m}\}. Each row in the datasets corresponds to a data sample, and each column corresponds to a feature. Let n𝑛n be the number of samples and disubscript𝑑𝑖d_{i} be the number of features in Disubscript𝐷𝑖{D}_{i}, where i∈{1,⋯,m}𝑖1⋯𝑚i\in\{1,\cdots,m\}. We denote Di={xi​t}t=1nsubscript𝐷𝑖superscriptsubscriptsubscriptx𝑖𝑡𝑡1𝑛D_{i}=\{\textbf{x}_{it}\}_{t=1}^{n} where xi​tsubscriptx𝑖𝑡\textbf{x}_{it} represents the t𝑡t-th sample of Disubscript𝐷𝑖D_{i}. Let Y={yt}t=1n𝑌superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑦𝑡𝑡1𝑛Y=\{y_{t}\}_{t=1}^{n} be the set of sample labels. Table 1 summarizes the frequently used notations.

Pivot focuses on the vertical federated learning scenario [77], where the datasets {D1,⋯,Dm}subscript𝐷1⋯subscript𝐷𝑚\{{D}_{1},\cdots,D_{m}\} share the same sample ids while with different features. In particular, we assume that the clients have determined and aligned their common samples using private set intersection techniques [54, 62, 19, 63] without revealing any information about samples not in the intersection. In addition, we assume that the label set Y𝑌Y is held by only one client (i.e., super client) and cannot be directly shared with other clients.

3.2 Threat Model

We consider the semi-honest model [57, 75, 74, 23, 22, 38] where every client follows the protocol exactly as specified, but may try to infer other clients’ private information based on the messages received. Like any other client, no additional trust is assumed of the super client. We assume that an adversary 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} can corrupt up to m−1𝑚1m-1 clients and the adversary’s corruption strategy is static, such that the set of corrupted clients is fixed before the protocol execution and remains unchanged during the execution.

3.3 Problem Formulation

To protect the private data of honest clients, we require that an adversary learns nothing more than the data of the clients he has corrupted and the final output. Similar to previous work [57, 81, 23], we formalize our problem under the ideal/real paradigm. Let ℱℱ\mathcal{F} be an ideal functionality such that the clients send their data to a trusted third party for computation and receive the final output from that party. Let π𝜋\pi be a real world protocol executed by the clients. We say a real protocol π𝜋\pi behaviors indistinguishably as the ideal functionality ℱℱ\mathcal{F} if the following formal definition is satisfied.

Definition 1.

([15, 25, 57]). A protocol π𝜋\pi securely realizes an ideal functionality ℱℱ\mathcal{F} if for every adversary 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} attacking the real interaction, there exists a simulator 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S} attacking the ideal interaction, such that for all environments 𝒵𝒵\mathcal{Z}, the following quantity is negligible (in λ𝜆\lambda):

|Pr​[real​(𝒵,𝒜,π,λ)=1]−Pr​[ideal​(𝒵,𝒮,ℱ,λ)=1]|.□formulae-sequencePrdelimited-[]real𝒵𝒜𝜋𝜆1Prdelimited-[]ideal𝒵𝒮ℱ𝜆1□\displaystyle\big{|}\text{Pr}[\textsc{real}(\mathcal{Z},\mathcal{A},\pi,\lambda)=1]-\text{Pr}[\textsc{ideal}(\mathcal{Z},\mathcal{S},\mathcal{F},\lambda)=1]\big{|}.\Box

In this paper, we identify two ideal functionalities ℱDTTsubscriptℱDTT\mathcal{F}_{\text{DTT}} and ℱDTPsubscriptℱDTP\mathcal{F}_{\text{DTP}} for the model training and model prediction, respectively. In ℱDTTsubscriptℱDTT\mathcal{F}_{\text{DTT}}, the input is every client’s dataset while the output is the trained model that all clients have agreed to release. In ℱDTPsubscriptℱDTP\mathcal{F}_{\text{DTP}}, the input is the released model and a sample while the output is the predicted label of that sample. The output of ℱDTTsubscriptℱDTT\mathcal{F}_{\text{DTT}} is part of the input of ℱDTPsubscriptℱDTP\mathcal{F}_{\text{DTP}}. Specifically, in our basic protocol (Section 4), we assume that the output of ℱDTTsubscriptℱDTT\mathcal{F}_{\text{DTT}} is the plaintext tree model, including the split feature and the split threshold on each internal node, and the label for prediction on each leaf node. While in our enhanced protocol (Section 5), the released plaintext information is assumed to include only the split feature on each internal node, whereas the split threshold and the leaf label are concealed for better privacy protection.

3.4 Protocol Overview

We now provide the protocol overview of Pivot. The protocols are composed of three stages: initialization, model training, and model prediction.

Initialization stage. In this stage, the m𝑚m clients agree to run a designated algorithm (i.e., the decision tree model) over their joint data and release the pre-defined information (e.g., the trained model) among themselves. The clients collaboratively determine and align the joint samples. The clients also build consensus on some hyper-parameters, such as security parameters (e.g., key size), pruning thresholds, and so on. The m𝑚m clients jointly generate the keys of threshold homomorphic encryption and every client uisubscript𝑢𝑖u_{i} receives the public key p​k𝑝𝑘pk and a partial secret key s​ki𝑠subscript𝑘𝑖{sk}_{i}.

Model training stage. The m𝑚m clients build the designated tree model iteratively. In each iteration, the super client first broadcasts some encrypted information to facilitate the other clients to compute encrypted necessary statistics at local. After that, the clients jointly convert those statistics into MPC-compatible inputs, i.e., secretly shared values, to determine the best split of the current tree node using secure computations. Finally, the secretly shared best split is revealed (in the Pivot basic protocol) or is converted back into an encrypted form (in the Pivot enhanced protocol), for clients to update the model. Throughout the whole process, no intermediate information is disclosed to any client.

Model prediction stage. After model training, the clients obtain a tree model. In the basic protocol of Pivot (Section 4), the whole tree is released in plaintext. In the Pivot enhanced protocol (Section 5), the split threshold on each internal node and the prediction label on each leaf node are concealed from all clients, in secretly shared form. Given an input sample with distributed feature values, the clients can jointly produce a prediction. Pivot guarantees that no information except for the predicted label is revealed during the prediction process.

4 Basic Protocol

In this section, we present our basic protocol of Pivot. The output of the model training stage is assumed to be the whole plaintext tree model. Note that prior work [71, 44, 67, 68, 69, 21, 50] is not applicable to our problem since they simplify the problem by revealing either the training labels or intermediate results in plaintext, which discloses too much information regarding the client’s private data.

To satisfy Definition 1 for vertical tree training, a straightforward solution is to directly use the MPC framework. For example, the clients can apply the additive secret sharing scheme (see Section 2.2) to convert private datasets and labels into secretly shared data, and train the model by secure computations. However, this solution incurs high communication complexity because it involves O​(n​d)𝑂𝑛𝑑O(nd) secretly shared values and most secure computations are communication intensive. On the other hand, while TPHE could enable each client to compute encrypted split statistics at local by providing the super client’s encrypted label information, it does not support some operations (e.g., comparison), which are needed in best split determination. Based on these observations and inspired by [81], we design our basic protocol using a hybrid framework of TPHE and MPC for vertical tree training. The basic idea is that each client executes as many local computations (e.g., computing split statistics) as possible with the help of TPHE and uses MPC only when TPHE is insufficient (e.g., deciding the best split). As a consequence, most computations are executed at local and the secretly shared values involved in MPC are reduced to O​(d​b)𝑂𝑑𝑏O(db), where b𝑏b denotes the maximum number of split values for any feature and d​b𝑑𝑏db is the number of total splits.

Section 4.1 and Section 4.2 present our training protocol for classification tree and regression tree, respectively. Section 4.3 proposes our tree model prediction method. The security analysis is provided in Section 4.4.

4.1 Classification Tree Training

In our training protocol, the clients use an mask vector of size n𝑛n to indicate which samples are available on a tree node, but keep the vector in an encrypted form to avoid disclosing the sample set. Specifically, let 𝜶=(α1,⋯,αn)𝜶subscript𝛼1⋯subscript𝛼𝑛\boldsymbol{\alpha}=(\alpha_{1},\cdots,\alpha_{n}) be an indicator vector for a tree node. Then, for any i∈{1,⋯,n}𝑖1⋯𝑛i\in\{1,\cdots,n\}, αi=1subscript𝛼𝑖1\alpha_{i}=1 indicates that the i𝑖i-th sample is available on the node, and αi=0subscript𝛼𝑖0\alpha_{i}=0 otherwise. We use [𝜶]=([α1],⋯,[αn])delimited-[]𝜶delimited-[]subscript𝛼1⋯delimited-[]subscript𝛼𝑛[\boldsymbol{\alpha}]=([\alpha_{1}],\cdots,[\alpha_{n}]) to denote the encrypted version of 𝜶𝜶\boldsymbol{\alpha}, where [⋅]delimited-[]⋅[\cdot] represents homomorphic encrypted values (see Section 2.1).

Before the training starts, each client initializes a decision tree with only a root node, and associates the root node with an encrypted indicator vector [𝜶]delimited-[]𝜶[\boldsymbol{\alpha}] where all elements are [1]delimited-[]1[1] (since all samples are available on the root node). Then, the clients work together to recursively split the root node. In what follows, we will use an example to illustrate how our protocol decides the best split for a given tree node based on Gini impurity.

Consider the example in Figure 2, where we have three clients u1subscript𝑢1u_{1}, u2subscript𝑢2u_{2}, and u3subscript𝑢3u_{3}. Among them, u1subscript𝑢1u_{1} is the super client, and she owns the labels with two classes, 111 and 222. There are five training samples with three features (i.e., income, age, and deposit), and each client holds one feature. Suppose that the clients are to split a tree node whose encrypted mask vector is [𝜶]=([1],[1],[1],[0],[1])delimited-[]𝜶delimited-[]1delimited-[]1delimited-[]1delimited-[]0delimited-[]1[\boldsymbol{\alpha}]=([1],[1],[1],[0],[1]), i.e., Samples 1, 2, 3, and 5 are on the node. Then, u1subscript𝑢1u_{1} computes an encrypted indicator vector for each class, based on [𝜶]delimited-[]𝜶[\boldsymbol{\alpha}] and her local labels. For example, for Class 1, u1subscript𝑢1u_{1} derives an temporary indicator vector (1,0,1,1,0)10110(1,0,1,1,0), which indicates that Samples 1, 3, and 4 belong to Class 1. Next, u1subscript𝑢1u_{1} uses the indicator vector to perform an element-wise homomorphic multiplication with [𝜶]delimited-[]𝜶[\boldsymbol{\alpha}], which results in an encrypted indicator vector [𝜸1]=([1],[0],[1],[0],[0])delimited-[]subscript𝜸1delimited-[]1delimited-[]0delimited-[]1delimited-[]0delimited-[]0[\boldsymbol{\gamma}_{1}]=([1],[0],[1],[0],[0]). This vector indicates that Samples 1 and 3 are on the node to be split, and they belong to Class 1. Similarly, u1subscript𝑢1u_{1} also generates an encrypted indicator vector [𝜸2]delimited-[]subscript𝜸2[\boldsymbol{\gamma}_{2}] for Class 2. After that, u1subscript𝑢1u_{1} broadcasts [𝜸1]delimited-[]subscript𝜸1[\boldsymbol{\gamma}_{1}] and [𝜸2]delimited-[]subscript𝜸2[\boldsymbol{\gamma}_{2}] to all clients.

After receiving [𝜸1]delimited-[]subscript𝜸1[\boldsymbol{\gamma}_{1}] and [𝜸2]delimited-[]subscript𝜸2[\boldsymbol{\gamma}_{2}], each client combines them with her local training data to compute several statistics that are required to choose the best split of the current node. In particular, to evaluate the quality of a split based on Gini impurity (see Section 2.3), each client needs to examine the two child nodes that would result from the split, and then compute the following statistics for each child node: (i) the total number of samples that belong to the child node, and (ii) the number of samples among them that are associated with label class k𝑘k, for each k∈K𝑘𝐾k\in K.

For example, suppose that u3subscript𝑢3u_{3} considers a split that divides the current node based on whether the deposit values are larger than 15000. Then, u3subscript𝑢3u_{3} first examines her local samples, and divide them into two partitions. The first partition (referred to as the left partition) consists of Samples 1, 2, and 4, i.e., the local samples whose deposit values are no more than 15000. Meanwhile, the second partition (referred to as the right partition) contains Samples 3 and 5. Accordingly, for the left (resp. right) partition, u3subscript𝑢3u_{3} constructs an indicator vector 𝒗l=(1,1,0,1,0)subscript𝒗𝑙11010\boldsymbol{v}_{l}=(1,1,0,1,0) (resp. 𝒗r=(0,0,1,0,1)subscript𝒗𝑟00101\boldsymbol{v}_{r}=(0,0,1,0,1)) to specify the samples that it contains. After that, u3subscript𝑢3u_{3} performs a homomorphic dot product between 𝒗lsubscript𝒗𝑙\boldsymbol{v}_{l} and [𝜸1]delimited-[]subscript𝜸1[\boldsymbol{\gamma}_{1}] to obtain an encrypted number [gl,1]delimited-[]subscript𝑔𝑙1[g_{l,1}]. Observe that gl,1subscript𝑔𝑙1g_{l,1} equals the exact number of Class 1 samples that belong to the left child node of the split. Similarly, u3subscript𝑢3u_{3} uses 𝒗lsubscript𝒗𝑙\boldsymbol{v}_{l} and [𝜸2]delimited-[]subscript𝜸2[\boldsymbol{\gamma}_{2}] to generate [gl,2]delimited-[]subscript𝑔𝑙2[g_{l,2}], an encrypted version of the number of Class 2 samples that belong to the left child node. Using the same approach, u3subscript𝑢3u_{3} also computes the encrypted numbers of Classes 1 and 2 samples associated with the right child node. Further, u3subscript𝑢3u_{3} derives an encrypted total number of samples in the left (resp. right) child node, using a homomorphic dot product between 𝒗lsubscript𝒗𝑙\boldsymbol{v}_{l} and [𝜶]delimited-[]𝜶[\boldsymbol{\alpha}] (resp. 𝒗rsubscript𝒗𝑟\boldsymbol{v}_{r} and [𝜶]delimited-[]𝜶[\boldsymbol{\alpha}]).

Suppose that each client computes the encrypted numbers associated with each possible split of the current node, using the approach illustrated for u3subscript𝑢3u_{3} above. Then, they can convert them into MPC-compatible inputs, and then invoke an MPC protocol to securely identify the best split of the current node. We will elaborate the details shortly.

In general, the clients split each node in three steps: local computation, MPC computation, and model update. In the following, we discuss the details of each step.

Local computation. Suppose that the clients are to split a node that is associated with an encrypted mask vector [𝜶]=([α1],⋯,[αn])delimited-[]𝜶delimited-[]subscript𝛼1⋯delimited-[]subscript𝛼𝑛[\boldsymbol{\alpha}]=([\alpha_{1}],\cdots,[\alpha_{n}]), indicating the available samples on the node. First, the super client constructs, for each class label k∈K𝑘𝐾k\in K, an auxiliary indicator vector 𝜷k=(βk,1,⋯,βk,n)subscript𝜷𝑘subscript𝛽𝑘1⋯subscript𝛽𝑘𝑛\boldsymbol{\beta}_{k}=(\beta_{k,1},\cdots,\beta_{k,n}), such that βk,t=1subscript𝛽𝑘𝑡1\beta_{k,t}=1 if Sample t𝑡t’s label is k𝑘k, and βk,t=0subscript𝛽𝑘𝑡0\beta_{k,t}=0 otherwise. After that, the super client performs an element-wise homomorphic multiplication between 𝜷ksubscript𝜷𝑘\boldsymbol{\beta}_{k} and [𝜶]delimited-[]𝜶[\boldsymbol{\alpha}], obtaining an encrypted indicator vector [𝜸k]delimited-[]subscript𝜸𝑘[\boldsymbol{\gamma}_{k}]. Then, the super client broadcasts [𝕃]=⋃k∈K{[𝜸k]}delimited-[]𝕃subscript𝑘𝐾delimited-[]subscript𝜸𝑘[\reflectbox{\rotatebox[origin={c}]{180.0}{$\mathbb{L}$}}]=\bigcup_{k\in K}\{[\boldsymbol{\gamma}_{k}]\} to the other clients.

Upon receiving [𝕃]delimited-[]𝕃[\reflectbox{\rotatebox[origin={c}]{180.0}{$\mathbb{L}$}}], each client uisubscript𝑢𝑖u_{i} uses it along with her local data to derive several statistics for identifying the tree node’s best split, as previously illustrated in our example. In particular, let Fisubscript𝐹𝑖F_{i} be the set of features that uisubscript𝑢𝑖u_{i} has, and Si​jsubscript𝑆𝑖𝑗S_{ij} be the set of split values for a feature j∈Fi𝑗subscript𝐹𝑖j\in F_{i}. Then, for any split value τ∈Si​j𝜏subscript𝑆𝑖𝑗\tau\in S_{ij}, uisubscript𝑢𝑖u_{i} first constructs two size-n𝑛n indicator vectors 𝒗lsubscript𝒗𝑙\boldsymbol{v}_{l} and 𝒗rsubscript𝒗𝑟\boldsymbol{v}_{r}, such that (i) the t𝑡t-th element in 𝒗lsubscript𝒗𝑙\boldsymbol{v}_{l} equals 1 if Sample t𝑡t’s feature j𝑗j is no more than τ𝜏\tau, and 0 otherwise, and (ii) 𝒗rsubscript𝒗𝑟\boldsymbol{v}_{r} complements 𝒗lsubscript𝒗𝑙\boldsymbol{v}_{l}. Consider the two possible child nodes induced by the split value τ𝜏\tau. For each class k∈K𝑘𝐾k\in K, let gl,ksubscript𝑔𝑙𝑘g_{l,k} (resp. gr,ksubscript𝑔𝑟𝑘g_{r,k}) be the number of samples labeled with class k𝑘k that belong to the left (resp. right) child node. uisubscript𝑢𝑖u_{i} computes the encrypted versions of gl,ksubscript𝑔𝑙𝑘g_{l,k} and gr,ksubscript𝑔𝑟𝑘g_{r,k} using homomorphic dot products (see Section 2.1) as follows:

[gl,k]=𝒗l⊙[𝜸k],[gr,k]=𝒗r⊙[𝜸k].formulae-sequencedelimited-[]subscript𝑔𝑙𝑘direct-productsubscript𝒗𝑙delimited-[]subscript𝜸𝑘delimited-[]subscript𝑔𝑟𝑘direct-productsubscript𝒗𝑟delimited-[]subscript𝜸𝑘\displaystyle[g_{l,k}]=\boldsymbol{v}_{l}\odot[\boldsymbol{\gamma}_{k}],\quad[g_{r,k}]=\boldsymbol{v}_{r}\odot[\boldsymbol{\gamma}_{k}]. (7)

Let nlsubscript𝑛𝑙n_{l} (resp. nrsubscript𝑛𝑟n_{r}) be the number of samples in the left (resp. right) child node. uisubscript𝑢𝑖u_{i} computes [nl]=𝒗l⊙[𝜶]delimited-[]subscript𝑛𝑙direct-productsubscript𝒗𝑙delimited-[]𝜶[n_{l}]=\boldsymbol{v}_{l}\odot[\boldsymbol{\alpha}] and [nr]=𝒗r⊙[𝜶]delimited-[]subscript𝑛𝑟direct-productsubscript𝒗𝑟delimited-[]𝜶[n_{r}]=\boldsymbol{v}_{r}\odot[\boldsymbol{\alpha}]. In total, for each split value τ𝜏\tau, uisubscript𝑢𝑖u_{i} generates 2⋅|K|+2⋅2𝐾22\cdot|K|+2 encrypted numbers, where |K|=c𝐾𝑐|K|=c is the number of classes.

MPC computation. After the clients generate the encrypted statistics mentioned above (i.e., [gl,k]delimited-[]subscript𝑔𝑙𝑘[g_{l,k}], [gr,k]delimited-[]subscript𝑔𝑟𝑘[g_{r,k}], [nl]delimited-[]subscript𝑛𝑙[n_{l}], [nr]delimited-[]subscript𝑛𝑟[n_{r}]), they execute an MPC protocol to identify the best split of the current node. Towards this end, the clients first invoke Algorithm 2 to convert each encrypted number [x]delimited-[]𝑥[x] into a set of secret shares {⟨x⟩i}i=1msuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptdelimited-⟨⟩𝑥𝑖𝑖1𝑚\{\langle x\rangle_{i}\}_{i=1}^{m}, where ⟨x⟩isubscriptdelimited-⟨⟩𝑥𝑖\langle x\rangle_{i} is given to uisubscript𝑢𝑖u_{i}. The general idea of Algorithm 2 is from [24, 28, 81]. We use ⟨x⟩delimited-⟨⟩𝑥\langle x\rangle to denote that the x𝑥x is secretly shared among the clients.

After the above conversion, the clients obtain secretly shared statistics ⟨nl⟩delimited-⟨⟩subscript𝑛𝑙\langle n_{l}\rangle, ⟨nr⟩delimited-⟨⟩subscript𝑛𝑟\langle n_{r}\rangle, ⟨gl,k⟩delimited-⟨⟩subscript𝑔𝑙𝑘\langle g_{l,k}\rangle, and ⟨gr,k⟩delimited-⟨⟩subscript𝑔𝑟𝑘\langle g_{r,k}\rangle (for each class k∈K𝑘𝐾k\in K) for each possible split τ𝜏\tau of the current node. Using these statistics, the clients identify the best split of the current node as follows.

Consider a split τ𝜏\tau and the two child nodes that it induces. To evaluate the Gini impurity of the left (resp. right) child node, the clients need to derive, for each class k∈K𝑘𝐾k\in K, the fraction pl,ksubscript𝑝𝑙𝑘p_{l,k} (resp. pr,ksubscript𝑝𝑟𝑘p_{r,k}) of samples on the node that are labeled with k𝑘k. Observe that

pl,k=gl,k∑k′∈Kgl,k′,pr,k=gr,k∑k′∈Kgr,k′.formulae-sequencesubscript𝑝𝑙𝑘subscript𝑔𝑙𝑘subscriptsuperscript𝑘′𝐾subscript𝑔𝑙superscript𝑘′subscript𝑝𝑟𝑘subscript𝑔𝑟𝑘subscriptsuperscript𝑘′𝐾subscript𝑔𝑟superscript𝑘′\displaystyle p_{l,k}=\frac{g_{l,k}}{\sum_{k^{\prime}\in K}g_{l,k^{\prime}}},\quad p_{r,k}=\frac{g_{r,k}}{\sum_{k^{\prime}\in K}g_{r,k^{\prime}}}. (8)

In addition, recall that the clients have obtained, for each class k∈K𝑘𝐾k\in K, the secretly shared values ⟨gl,k⟩delimited-⟨⟩subscript𝑔𝑙𝑘\langle g_{l,k}\rangle and ⟨gr,k⟩delimited-⟨⟩subscript𝑔𝑟𝑘\langle g_{r,k}\rangle. Therefore, the clients can jointly compute ⟨pl,k⟩delimited-⟨⟩subscript𝑝𝑙𝑘\langle p_{l,k}\rangle and ⟨pr,k⟩delimited-⟨⟩subscript𝑝𝑟𝑘\langle p_{r,k}\rangle using the secure addition and secure division operators in SPDZ (see Section 2.2), without disclosing pl,ksubscript𝑝𝑙𝑘p_{l,k} and pr,ksubscript𝑝𝑟𝑘p_{r,k} to any client. With the same approach, the clients use ⟨nl⟩delimited-⟨⟩subscript𝑛𝑙\langle n_{l}\rangle and ⟨nr⟩delimited-⟨⟩subscript𝑛𝑟\langle n_{r}\rangle to securely compute ⟨wl⟩delimited-⟨⟩subscript𝑤𝑙\langle w_{l}\rangle and ⟨wr⟩delimited-⟨⟩subscript𝑤𝑟\langle w_{r}\rangle, where wl=nlnl+nrsubscript𝑤𝑙subscript𝑛𝑙subscript𝑛𝑙subscript𝑛𝑟w_{l}=\frac{n_{l}}{n_{l}+n_{r}} and wr=nrnl+nrsubscript𝑤𝑟subscript𝑛𝑟subscript𝑛𝑙subscript𝑛𝑟w_{r}=\frac{n_{r}}{n_{l}+n_{r}}. Given ⟨pl,k⟩delimited-⟨⟩subscript𝑝𝑙𝑘\langle p_{l,k}\rangle, ⟨pr,k⟩delimited-⟨⟩subscript𝑝𝑟𝑘\langle p_{r,k}\rangle, ⟨wl⟩delimited-⟨⟩subscript𝑤𝑙\langle w_{l}\rangle, and ⟨wr⟩delimited-⟨⟩subscript𝑤𝑟\langle w_{r}\rangle, the clients can then compute the impurity gain of each split τ𝜏\tau (see Eqn. (2.3)) in secretly shared form, using the secure addition and secure multiplication operators in SPDZ.

Finally, the clients jointly determine the best split using a secure maximum computation as follows. First, each client uisubscript𝑢𝑖u_{i} assigns an identifier (i,j,s)𝑖𝑗𝑠(i,j,s) to the s𝑠s-th split on the j𝑗j-th feature that she holds. Next, the clients initialize four secretly shared values ⟨gainmax⟩delimited-⟨⟩subscriptgainmax\langle\text{\it gain}_{\text{\it max}}\rangle, ⟨i∗⟩delimited-⟨⟩superscript𝑖\langle i^{*}\rangle, ⟨j∗⟩delimited-⟨⟩superscript𝑗\langle j^{*}\rangle, ⟨s∗⟩delimited-⟨⟩superscript𝑠\langle s^{*}\rangle, all with ⟨−1⟩delimited-⟨⟩1\langle-1\rangle. After that, they will compare the secretly shared impurity gains of all splits, and securely record the identifier and impurity gain of the best split in ⟨i∗⟩delimited-⟨⟩superscript𝑖\langle i^{*}\rangle, ⟨j∗⟩delimited-⟨⟩superscript𝑗\langle j^{*}\rangle, ⟨s∗⟩delimited-⟨⟩superscript𝑠\langle s^{*}\rangle, and ⟨gainmax⟩delimited-⟨⟩subscriptgainmax\langle\text{\it gain}_{\text{\it max}}\rangle, respectively. Specifically, for each split τ𝜏\tau, the clients compare its impurity gain ⟨gainτ⟩delimited-⟨⟩subscriptgain𝜏\langle\text{\it gain}_{\tau}\rangle with ⟨gainmax⟩delimited-⟨⟩subscriptgainmax\langle\text{\it gain}_{\text{\it max}}\rangle using secure comparison (see Section 2.2). Let ⟨sign⟩delimited-⟨⟩sign\langle\text{\it sign}\rangle be the result of the secure comparison, i.e., sign=1sign1\text{\it sign}=1 if gainτ>gainmaxsubscriptgain𝜏subscriptgainmax\text{\it gain}_{\tau}>\text{\it gain}_{\text{\it max}}, and sign=0sign0\text{\it sign}=0 otherwise. Then, the clients securely update ⟨gainmax⟩delimited-⟨⟩subscriptgainmax\langle\text{\it gain}_{\text{\it max}}\rangle using the secretly shared values, such that gainmax=gainmax⋅(1−sign)+gainτ⋅signsubscriptgainmax⋅subscriptgainmax1sign⋅subscriptgain𝜏sign\text{\it gain}_{\text{\it max}}=\text{\it gain}_{\text{\it max}}\cdot(1-\text{\it sign})+\text{\it gain}_{\tau}\cdot\text{\it sign}. The best split identifier is updated in the same manner. After examining all splits, the clients obtain the secretly shared best split identifier (⟨i∗⟩,⟨j∗⟩,⟨s∗⟩)delimited-⟨⟩superscript𝑖delimited-⟨⟩superscript𝑗delimited-⟨⟩superscript𝑠(\langle i^{*}\rangle,\langle j^{*}\rangle,\langle s^{*}\rangle).

Model update. Recall that in the basic protocol, the tree model can be released in plaintext. Therefore, the clients reconstruct the secretly shared identifier. Then, the i∗superscript𝑖i^{*}-th client can retrieve the two indicator vectors 𝒗lsubscript𝒗𝑙\boldsymbol{v}_{l} and 𝒗rsubscript𝒗𝑟\boldsymbol{v}_{r} for the s∗superscript𝑠s^{*}-th split of the j∗superscript𝑗j^{*}-th feature. After that, she executes element-wise homomorphic multiplication on the two vectors by [𝜶]delimited-[]𝜶[\boldsymbol{\alpha}], obtaining [𝜶l]delimited-[]subscript𝜶𝑙[\boldsymbol{\alpha}_{l}] and [𝜶r]delimited-[]subscript𝜶𝑟[\boldsymbol{\alpha}_{r}] for the two branches, and broadcasts them to the other clients. Note that [𝜶l]delimited-[]subscript𝜶𝑙[\boldsymbol{\alpha}_{l}] and [𝜶r]delimited-[]subscript𝜶𝑟[\boldsymbol{\alpha}_{r}] exactly specify the available samples on the two child nodes, respectively. For example, in Figure 2, if the current split of the ‘deposit’ feature is selected, u3subscript𝑢3u_{3} can compute [𝜶l]=([1],[1],[0],[0],[0])delimited-[]subscript𝜶𝑙delimited-[]1delimited-[]1delimited-[]0delimited-[]0delimited-[]0[\boldsymbol{\alpha}_{l}]=([1],[1],[0],[0],[0]) using 𝒗lsubscript𝒗𝑙\boldsymbol{v}_{l} and [𝜶]delimited-[]𝜶[\boldsymbol{\alpha}], indicating that Samples 1 and 2 are available on the left child node.

4.2 Regression Tree Training

For the regression tree, since the label is continuous, the central part is to compute the label variance. The MPC computation step and model update step are similar to that of classification, thus, we only present the difference in the local computation step.

According to the label variance formula Eqn. (6), the super client can construct two auxiliary vectors 𝜷1=(y1,⋯,yn)subscript𝜷1subscript𝑦1⋯subscript𝑦𝑛\boldsymbol{\beta}_{1}=(y_{1},\cdots,y_{n}) and 𝜷2=(y12,⋯,yn2)subscript𝜷2superscriptsubscript𝑦12⋯superscriptsubscript𝑦𝑛2\boldsymbol{\beta}_{2}=(y_{1}^{2},\cdots,y_{n}^{2}), where the elements in 𝜷1subscript𝜷1\boldsymbol{\beta}_{1} are the original training labels while the elements in 𝜷2subscript𝜷2\boldsymbol{\beta}_{2} are the square of the original training labels. Next, she computes element-wise homomorphic multiplication on 𝜷1subscript𝜷1\boldsymbol{\beta}_{1} (resp. 𝜷2subscript𝜷2\boldsymbol{\beta}_{2}) by [𝜶]delimited-[]𝜶[\boldsymbol{\alpha}], obtaining [𝜸1]delimited-[]subscript𝜸1[\boldsymbol{\gamma}_{1}] (resp. [𝜸2]delimited-[]subscript𝜸2[\boldsymbol{\gamma}_{2}]). Then, she broadcasts [𝕃]={[𝜸1],[𝜸2]}delimited-[]𝕃delimited-[]subscript𝜸1delimited-[]subscript𝜸2[\reflectbox{\rotatebox[origin={c}]{180.0}{$\mathbb{L}$}}]=\{[\boldsymbol{\gamma}_{1}],[\boldsymbol{\gamma}_{2}]\} to all clients. Similarly, each client computes the following encrypted statistics for any local split:

[nl]=𝒗l⊙[𝜶],[gl,1]=𝒗l⊙[𝜸1],[gl,2]=𝒗l⊙[𝜸2]formulae-sequencedelimited-[]subscript𝑛𝑙direct-productsubscript𝒗𝑙delimited-[]𝜶formulae-sequencedelimited-[]subscript𝑔𝑙1direct-productsubscript𝒗𝑙delimited-[]subscript𝜸1delimited-[]subscript𝑔𝑙2direct-productsubscript𝒗𝑙delimited-[]subscript𝜸2\displaystyle[n_{l}]=\boldsymbol{v}_{l}\odot[\boldsymbol{\alpha}],\quad[g_{l,1}]=\boldsymbol{v}_{l}\odot[\boldsymbol{\gamma}_{1}],\quad[g_{l,2}]=\boldsymbol{v}_{l}\odot[\boldsymbol{\gamma}_{2}] (9)

where [nl],[gl,1],[gl,2]delimited-[]subscript𝑛𝑙delimited-[]subscript𝑔𝑙1delimited-[]subscript𝑔𝑙2[n_{l}],[g_{l,1}],[g_{l,2}] are the encrypted number of samples, and the encrypted sum of [𝜸1]delimited-[]subscript𝜸1[\boldsymbol{\gamma}_{1}] and [𝜸2]delimited-[]subscript𝜸2[\boldsymbol{\gamma}_{2}] of the available samples, for the left branch. Similarly, these encrypted statistics can be converted into secretly shared values and the best split identifier can be decided based on Eqn. (6).

Algorithm 3 describes the privacy preserving decision tree training protocol. Lines 1-3 check the pruning conditions and compute the leaf label if any condition is satisfied. Note that with the encrypted statistics, these executions can be easily achieved by secure computations. Lines 5-13 find the best split and build the tree recursively, where lines 5-9 are the local computation step for computing encrypted split statistics; line 10-11 are the MPC computation step that converts the encrypted statistics into secretly shared values and decides the best split identifier using MPC; and line 12 is the model update step, which computes the encrypted indicator vectors for the child nodes given the best split.

4.3 Tree Model Prediction

After releasing the plaintext tree model, the clients can jointly make a prediction given a sample. In vertical FL, the features of a sample are distributed among the clients. Figure 3(a) shows an example of a released model, where each internal node represents a feature with a split threshold owned by a client, and each leaf node represents a predicted label on that path. To predict a sample, a naive method is to let the super client coordinate the prediction process [21]: starting from the root node, the client who has the node feature compares its value with the split threshold, and notifies super client the next branch; then the prediction is forwarded to the next node until a leaf node is reached. However, this method discloses the prediction path, from which a client can infer the other client’s feature value along that path.

To ensure that no additional information other than the predicted output is leaked, we propose a distributed prediction method, as shown in Algorithm 4. Let 𝒛=(z1,⋯,zt+1)𝒛subscript𝑧1⋯subscript𝑧𝑡1\boldsymbol{z}=(z_{1},\cdots,z_{t+1}) be the leaf label vector of the leaf nodes in the tree model, where t𝑡t is the number of internal nodes. Note that all clients know 𝒛𝒛\boldsymbol{z} since the tree model is public in this protocol. Given a sample, clients collaborate to update an encrypted prediction vector [𝜼]=([1],⋯,[1])delimited-[]𝜼delimited-[]1⋯delimited-[]1[\boldsymbol{\eta}]=([1],\cdots,[1]) with size t+1𝑡1t+1 in a round-robin manner. Each element in [𝜼]delimited-[]𝜼[\boldsymbol{\eta}] indicates if a prediction path is possible with encrypted form.

Without loss of generality, we assume that the prediction starts with umsubscript𝑢𝑚u_{m} and ends with u1subscript𝑢1u_{1}. If a prediction path is possible from the perspective of a client, then the client multiplies the designated element in [𝜼]delimited-[]𝜼[\boldsymbol{\eta}] by 1 using homomorphic multiplication, otherwise by 0. Figure 3(b) illustrates an example of this method. Starting from u3subscript𝑢3u_{3}, given the feature value ‘deposit = 6000’, u3subscript𝑢3u_{3} initializes [𝜼]delimited-[]𝜼[\boldsymbol{\eta}] and updates it to ([0],[1],[1],[0],[1])delimited-[]0delimited-[]1delimited-[]1delimited-[]0delimited-[]1([0],[1],[1],[0],[1]), since she can eliminate the first and fourth prediction paths after comparing her value with the split threshold ‘deposit = 5000’. Then, u3subscript𝑢3u_{3} sends [𝜼]delimited-[]𝜼[\boldsymbol{\eta}] to the next client for updates. After all clients’ updates, there is only one [1]delimited-[]1[1] in [𝜼]delimited-[]𝜼[\boldsymbol{\eta}], which indicates the true prediction path. Finally, u1subscript𝑢1u_{1} computes 𝒛⊙[𝜼]direct-product𝒛delimited-[]𝜼\boldsymbol{z}\odot[\boldsymbol{\eta}] to get the encrypted prediction output, and decrypts it jointly with all clients.

4.4 Security Guarantees

Theorem 1.

The basic protocol of Pivot securely realizes the ideal functionalities ℱDTTsubscriptℱDTT\mathcal{F}_{\text{DTT}} and ℱDTPsubscriptℱDTP\mathcal{F}_{\text{DTP}} against a semi-honest adversary who can statically corrupt up to m−1𝑚1m-1 out of m𝑚m clients.

Proof Sketch. We need to show that, in the view of an adversary 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}, any information learned by the protocol can be learned directly from the input it has corrupted and the output it receives.

For model training, the proof can be reduced to the computations on one tree node because each node can be computed separately given that its output is public [47, 48]. There are two cases. First, when a given node is an internal node: (i) if the super client is corrupted, nothing is revealed in the local computation step regarding the honest client’s data; while the MPC conversion [24] and additive secret sharing scheme [28] are secure, thus, the MPC computation step is secure; finally, in the model update step, if i∗superscript𝑖i^{*} is an honest client, the transmitted message [𝜶]delimited-[]𝜶[\boldsymbol{\alpha}] is secure for the threshold Paillier scheme [61] is secure. (ii) if the super client is not corrupted, the only difference is the transmitted encrypted label information [𝕃]delimited-[]𝕃[\reflectbox{\rotatebox[origin={c}]{180.0}{$\mathbb{L}$}}], which is also secure. Second, when a given node is a leaf node: (i) if the super client is corrupted, nothing is revealed since the honest client does not have the labels; (ii) if the super client is not corrupted, the transmitted messages are the encrypted sample number of each class (for classification) and the encrypted mean label (for regression), which are secure. Therefore, 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} learns no additional information from the protocol execution, the security follows.

For model prediction, the adversary 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} views an encrypted prediction vector [𝜼]delimited-[]𝜼[\boldsymbol{\eta}] updated by the honest client(s) and the encrypted prediction output [k¯]delimited-[]¯𝑘[\bar{k}], thus, no more information is learned (the decrypted prediction output is public) for the threshold Paillier scheme is secure. □□\Box

5 Enhanced Protocol

The basic protocol guarantees that no intermediate information is disclosed. However, after obtaining the public model, colluding clients may extract private information of a target client’s training dataset, with the help of their own datasets. We first present two possible privacy leakages in Section 5.1 and then propose an enhanced protocol that mitigates this problem by concealing some model information in Section 5.2. The security analysis is given in Section 5.3.

5.1 Privacy Leakages

We identify two possible privacy leakages: the training label leakage and the feature value leakage, regarding a target client’s training dataset. The intuition behind the leakages is that the colluding clients are able to split the sample set based on the split information in the model and their own datasets. We illustrate them by the following two examples given the tree model in Figure 3.

Example 1.

(Training label leakage). Assume that u2subscript𝑢2u_{2} and u3subscript𝑢3u_{3} collude, let us see the right branch of the root node. u2subscript𝑢2u_{2} knows exactly the sample set in this branch, say Dage > 30subscript𝐷age > 30D_{\text{age $>$ 30}}, as all samples are available on the root node and he can just split his local samples based on ‘age = 30’. Then, u3subscript𝑢3u_{3} can classify this set into two subsets given the ‘deposit=5000’ split, say Dage > 30​⋀deposit ≤ 5000subscript𝐷age > 30deposit ≤ 5000D_{\text{age $>$ 30}\bigwedge\text{deposit $\leq$ 5000}} and Dage > 30​⋀deposit > 5000subscript𝐷age > 30deposit > 5000D_{\text{age $>$ 30}\bigwedge\text{deposit $>$ 5000}}, respectively. Consequently, according to the plaintext class labels on the two leaf nodes, colluding clients may infer that the samples in Dage > 30​⋀deposit ≤ 5000subscript𝐷age > 30deposit ≤ 5000D_{\text{age $>$ 30}\bigwedge\text{deposit $\leq$ 5000}} are with class 2 and vise versa, with high probability.

Example 2.

(Feature value leakage). Assume that u1subscript𝑢1u_{1} and u2subscript𝑢2u_{2} collude, let us see the path of u2→u1→u3→subscript𝑢2subscript𝑢1→subscript𝑢3u_{2}\rightarrow u_{1}\rightarrow u_{3} (with red arrows). Similar to Example 1, u1subscript𝑢1u_{1} and u2subscript𝑢2u_{2} can exactly know the training sample set on the ‘u3subscript𝑢3u_{3}’ node before splitting, say D′superscript𝐷′D^{\prime}. In addition, recall that u1subscript𝑢1u_{1} is the super client who has all sample labels, thus, he can easily classify D′superscript𝐷′{D}^{\prime} into two sets by class, say D1′superscriptsubscript𝐷1′{D}_{1}^{\prime} and D2′superscriptsubscript𝐷2′{D}_{2}^{\prime}, respectively. Consequently, the colluding clients may infer that the samples in D2′superscriptsubscript𝐷2′{D}_{2}^{\prime} have ‘deposit ≤\leq 5000’ and vise versa, with high probability.

Note that these two leakages happen when the clients (except the target client) along a path collude. Essentially, given the model, the colluding clients (without super client) may infer labels of some samples in the training dataset if there is no feature belongs to the super client along a tree path; similarly, if the super client involves in collusion, the feature values of some samples in the training dataset of a target client may be inferred.

5.2 Hiding Label and Split Threshold

Our observation is that these privacy leakages can be mitigated if the split thresholds on the internal nodes and the leaf labels on the leaf nodes in the model are concealed from all clients. Without such information, the colluding clients can neither determine how to split the sample set nor what leaf label a path owns. We now discuss how to hide these information in the model.

For the leaf label on each leaf node, the clients can convert it to an encrypted value, instead of reconstructing its plaintext. Specifically, after obtaining the secretly shared leaf label (e.g., ⟨k⟩delimited-⟨⟩𝑘\langle k\rangle) using secure computations (Lines 1-3 in Algorithm 3), each client encrypts her own share of ⟨k⟩delimited-⟨⟩𝑘\langle k\rangle and broadcasts to all clients. Then, the encrypted leaf label can be computed by summing up these encrypted shares using homomorphic addition. As such, the leaf label is concealed.

For the split threshold on each internal node, the clients hide it by two additional computations in the model update step. Recall that in the basic protocol, the best split identifier (⟨i∗⟩,⟨j∗⟩,⟨s∗⟩)delimited-⟨⟩superscript𝑖delimited-⟨⟩superscript𝑗delimited-⟨⟩superscript𝑠(\langle i^{*}\rangle,\langle j^{*}\rangle,\langle s^{*}\rangle) is revealed to all clients after the MPC computation in each iteration. In the enhanced protocol, we assume that ⟨s∗⟩delimited-⟨⟩superscript𝑠\langle s^{*}\rangle is not revealed, thus the split threshold can be concealed. To support the tree model update without disclosing s∗superscript𝑠s^{*} to the i∗superscript𝑖i^{*}-th client, we first use the private information retrieval (PIR) [75, 74] technique to privately select the split indicator vectors of s∗superscript𝑠s^{*}.

Private split selection. Let n′=|Si​j|superscript𝑛′subscript𝑆𝑖𝑗n^{\prime}=|S_{ij}| denote the number of splits of the j∗superscript𝑗j^{*}-th feature of the i∗superscript𝑖i^{*}-th client. We assume n′superscript𝑛′n^{\prime} is public for simplicity. Note that the clients can further protect n′superscript𝑛′n^{\prime} by padding placeholders to a pre-defined threshold number. Instead of revealing ⟨s∗⟩delimited-⟨⟩superscript𝑠\langle s^{*}\rangle to the i∗superscript𝑖i^{*}-th client, the clients jointly convert ⟨s∗⟩delimited-⟨⟩superscript𝑠\langle s^{*}\rangle into an encrypted indicator vector [𝝀]=([λ1],⋯,[λn′])Tdelimited-[]𝝀superscriptdelimited-[]subscript𝜆1⋯delimited-[]subscript𝜆superscript𝑛′𝑇[\boldsymbol{\lambda}]=([\lambda_{1}],\cdots,[\lambda_{n^{\prime}}])^{T}, such that λt=1subscript𝜆𝑡1\lambda_{t}=1 when t=s∗𝑡superscript𝑠t=s^{*} and λt=0subscript𝜆𝑡0\lambda_{t}=0 otherwise, where t∈{1,⋯,n′}𝑡1⋯superscript𝑛′t\in\{1,\cdots,n^{\prime}\}. This vector is sent to the i∗superscript𝑖i^{*}-th client for private split selection at local. Let 𝑽n×n′=(𝒗1,⋯,𝒗n′)superscript𝑽𝑛superscript𝑛′subscript𝒗1⋯subscript𝒗superscript𝑛′{\boldsymbol{V}}^{n\times n^{\prime}}=(\boldsymbol{v}_{1},\cdots,\boldsymbol{v}_{n^{\prime}}) be the split indicator matrix, where 𝒗tsubscript𝒗𝑡\boldsymbol{v}_{t} is the split indicator vector of the t𝑡t-th split of the j∗superscript𝑗j^{*}-th feature (see Section 4.1). The following theorem [74] suggests that the i∗superscript𝑖i^{*}-th client can compute the encrypted indicator vector for the s∗superscript𝑠s^{*}-th split without disclosing s∗superscript𝑠s^{*}.

Theorem 2.

Given an encrypted indicator vector [𝛌]=([λ1],⋯,[λn′])Tdelimited-[]𝛌superscriptdelimited-[]subscript𝜆1⋯delimited-[]subscript𝜆superscript𝑛′𝑇[\boldsymbol{\lambda}]=([\lambda_{1}],\cdots,[\lambda_{n^{\prime}}])^{T} such that [λs∗]=[1]delimited-[]subscript𝜆superscript𝑠delimited-[]1[\lambda_{s^{*}}]=[1] and [λt]=[0]delimited-[]subscript𝜆𝑡delimited-[]0[\lambda_{t}]=[0] for all t≠s∗𝑡superscript𝑠t\neq s^{*}, and the indicator matrix 𝐕n×n′=(𝐯1,⋯,𝐯n′)superscript𝐕𝑛superscript𝑛′subscript𝐯1⋯subscript𝐯superscript𝑛′{\boldsymbol{V}}^{n\times n^{\prime}}=(\boldsymbol{v}_{1},\cdots,\boldsymbol{v}_{n^{\prime}}), then [𝐯s∗]=𝐕​⨂[𝛌]delimited-[]subscript𝐯superscript𝑠𝐕tensor-productdelimited-[]𝛌[\boldsymbol{v}_{s^{*}}]=\boldsymbol{V}\bigotimes[\boldsymbol{\lambda}]. □□\Box

The notion ⨂tensor-product\bigotimes represents the homomorphic matrix multiplication, which executes homomorphic dot product operations between each row in 𝑽𝑽\boldsymbol{V} and [𝝀]delimited-[]𝝀[\boldsymbol{\lambda}]. We refer the interested readers to [74] for the details.

For simplicity, we denote the selected [𝒗s∗]delimited-[]subscript𝒗superscript𝑠[\boldsymbol{v}_{s^{*}}] as [𝒗]delimited-[]𝒗[\boldsymbol{v}]. The encrypted split threshold can also be obtained by homomorphic dot product between the encrypted indicator vector [𝝀]delimited-[]𝝀[\boldsymbol{\lambda}] and the plaintext split value vector of the j∗superscript𝑗j^{*}-th feature.

Encrypted mask vector updating. After finding the encrypted split vector [𝒗]delimited-[]𝒗[\boldsymbol{v}], we need to update the encrypted mask vector [𝜶]delimited-[]𝜶[\boldsymbol{\alpha}] for protecting the sample set recursively. This requires element-wise multiplication between [𝜶]delimited-[]𝜶[\boldsymbol{\alpha}] and [𝒗]delimited-[]𝒗[\boldsymbol{v}]. Thanks to the MPC conversion algorithm, we can compute [𝜶]⋅[𝒗]⋅delimited-[]𝜶delimited-[]𝒗[\boldsymbol{\alpha}]\cdot[\boldsymbol{v}] as follows [24]. For each element pair [αj]delimited-[]subscript𝛼𝑗[\alpha_{j}] and [vj]delimited-[]subscript𝑣𝑗[v_{j}] where j∈[1,n]𝑗1𝑛j\in[1,n], we first convert [αj]delimited-[]subscript𝛼𝑗[\alpha_{j}] into ⟨αj⟩=(⟨αj⟩1,⋯,⟨αj⟩m)delimited-⟨⟩subscript𝛼𝑗subscriptdelimited-⟨⟩subscript𝛼𝑗1⋯subscriptdelimited-⟨⟩subscript𝛼𝑗𝑚\langle\alpha_{j}\rangle=({\langle\alpha_{j}\rangle}_{1},\cdots,{\langle\alpha_{j}\rangle}_{m}) using Algorithm 2, where ⟨αj⟩i​(i∈{1,⋯,m})subscriptdelimited-⟨⟩subscript𝛼𝑗𝑖𝑖1⋯𝑚{\langle\alpha_{j}\rangle}_{i}(i\in\{1,\cdots,m\}) is the share hold by uisubscript𝑢𝑖u_{i}; then each client uisubscript𝑢𝑖u_{i} executes homomorphic multiplication ⟨αj⟩i⊗[vj]=[⟨αj⟩i⋅vj]tensor-productsubscriptdelimited-⟨⟩subscript𝛼𝑗𝑖delimited-[]subscript𝑣𝑗delimited-[]⋅subscriptdelimited-⟨⟩subscript𝛼𝑗𝑖subscript𝑣𝑗{\langle\alpha_{j}\rangle}_{i}\otimes[v_{j}]=[{\langle\alpha_{j}\rangle}_{i}\cdot v_{j}] and sends the result to the i∗superscript𝑖i^{*}-th client; finally, the i∗superscript𝑖i^{*}-th client can sum up the results using homomorphic addition:

[αj′]delimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝛼𝑗′\displaystyle[\alpha_{j}^{\prime}] =[⟨αj⟩1⋅vj]⊕⋯⊕[⟨αj⟩m⋅vj]=[αj⋅vj]absentdirect-sumdelimited-[]⋅subscriptdelimited-⟨⟩subscript𝛼𝑗1subscript𝑣𝑗⋯delimited-[]⋅subscriptdelimited-⟨⟩subscript𝛼𝑗𝑚subscript𝑣𝑗delimited-[]⋅subscript𝛼𝑗subscript𝑣𝑗\displaystyle=[{\langle\alpha_{j}\rangle}_{1}\cdot v_{j}]\oplus\cdots\oplus[{\langle\alpha_{j}\rangle}_{m}\cdot v_{j}]=[\alpha_{j}\cdot v_{j}] (10)

After updating [𝜶]delimited-[]𝜶[\boldsymbol{\alpha}], the tree can also be built recursively, similar to the basic protocol.

Secret sharing based model prediction. The prediction method in the basic protocol is not applicable here as the clients cannot directly compare their feature values with the encrypted split thresholds. Hence, the clients first convert the encrypted split thresholds and encrypted leaf labels into secretly shared form and make predictions on the secretly shared model using MPC. Let ⟨𝒛⟩delimited-⟨⟩𝒛\langle\boldsymbol{z}\rangle with size (t+1)𝑡1(t+1) denote the secretly shared leaf label vector, where t𝑡t is the number of internal nodes.

To make the prediction given a sample, the clients also provide the distributed feature values in secretly shared form. Similar to the prediction in the basic protocol, the clients initialize a secretly shared prediction vector ⟨𝜼⟩delimited-⟨⟩𝜼\langle\boldsymbol{\eta}\rangle with size (t+1)𝑡1(t+1), indicating if a prediction path is possible. Then, they compute this vector as follows.

The clients initialize a secretly shared marker ⟨1⟩delimited-⟨⟩1\langle 1\rangle for the root node. Starting from root node, the clients recursively compute the markers of its child nodes until all leaf nodes are reached. Then, the marker of each leaf node is assigned to the corresponding position in ⟨𝜼⟩delimited-⟨⟩𝜼\langle\boldsymbol{\eta}\rangle, and there is only one ⟨1⟩delimited-⟨⟩1\langle 1\rangle element in ⟨𝜼⟩delimited-⟨⟩𝜼\langle\boldsymbol{\eta}\rangle, specifying the real prediction path in a secret manner. Specifically, each marker is computed by secure multiplication between its parent node’s marker and a secure comparison result (between the secretly shared feature value and split threshold on this node). For example, in Figure 3(a), the split threshold on the root node will be ⟨30⟩delimited-⟨⟩30\langle 30\rangle while the feature value will be ⟨25⟩delimited-⟨⟩25\langle 25\rangle, then ⟨1⟩delimited-⟨⟩1\langle 1\rangle is assigned to its left child and ⟨0⟩delimited-⟨⟩0\langle 0\rangle to its right child. The clients know nothing about the assigned markers due to the computations are secure. Finally, the secretly shared prediction output can be computed easily by a dot product between ⟨𝒛⟩delimited-⟨⟩𝒛\langle\boldsymbol{z}\rangle and ⟨𝜼⟩delimited-⟨⟩𝜼\langle\boldsymbol{\eta}\rangle, using secure computations.

Discussion. A noteworthy aspect is that the clients can also choose to hide the feature ⟨j∗⟩delimited-⟨⟩superscript𝑗\langle j^{*}\rangle by defining n′superscript𝑛′n^{\prime} as the total number of splits on the i∗superscript𝑖i^{*}-th client, or even the client ⟨i∗⟩delimited-⟨⟩superscript𝑖\langle i^{*}\rangle that has the best feature by defining n′superscript𝑛′n^{\prime} as the total number of splits among all clients. By doing so, the leakages could be further alleviated. However, the efficiency and interpretability would be degraded greatly. In fact, there is a trade-off between privacy and efficiency (interpretability) for the released model. The less information the model reveals, the higher privacy while the lower efficiency and less interpretability the clients obtain, and vise versa.

5.3 Security Guarantees

Theorem 3.

The enhanced protocol of Pivot securely realizes the ideal functionalities ℱDTTsubscriptℱDTT\mathcal{F}_{\text{DTT}} and ℱDTPsubscriptℱDTP\mathcal{F}_{\text{DTP}} against a semi-honest adversary who can statically corrupt up to m−1𝑚1m-1 out of m𝑚m clients.

Proof Sketch. For model training, the only difference from the basic protocol is the two additional computations (private split selection and encrypted mask vector updating) in the model update step, which are computed using threshold Paillier scheme and MPC conversion. Thus, the security follows. For model prediction, since the additive secret sharing scheme is secure and the clients compute a secretly shared marker for every possible path, the adversary learns nothing except the final prediction output. □□\Box

6 Theoretical Analysis

We theoretically analyze the Pivot basic protocol and Pivot enhanced protocol in terms of computational cost for model training and model prediction, as summarized in Table 2. Let Cesubscript𝐶𝑒C_{e} and Cssubscript𝐶𝑠C_{s} roughly denote the costs for computations on a homomorphic encrypted value and on a secretly shared value, respectively. Due to that the threshold decryption (involving decryption of each client and combination via network communication) and secure comparison (involving multi-round network communications among the clients) are more time-consuming than the other computations, we consider these two operations separately for better analysis, and denote the costs of them by Cdsubscript𝐶𝑑C_{d} and Ccsubscript𝐶𝑐C_{c}, respectively. Let d¯=max⁡({di}i=1m)¯𝑑superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑑𝑖𝑖1𝑚\bar{d}=\max(\{d_{i}\}_{i=1}^{m}) be the maximum number of features any client holds, b𝑏b be the maximum number of splits any feature has, and c𝑐c be the number of classes.

Model training. With the basic protocol, the computational cost of a client in each iteration includes: (i) local computation step: the encrypted label vectors computed by the super client, i.e., O​(n​c)​Ce𝑂𝑛𝑐subscript𝐶𝑒O(nc)C_{e}, and the encrypted statistics computed by the clients, i.e., O​(n​c​d¯​b)​Ce𝑂𝑛𝑐¯𝑑𝑏subscript𝐶𝑒O(nc\bar{d}b)C_{e}, where d¯​b¯𝑑𝑏\bar{d}b is number of local splits; (ii) MPC computation step: the MPC conversion for encrypted statistics of total splits, i.e., O​(c​d​b)​Cd𝑂𝑐𝑑𝑏subscript𝐶𝑑O(cdb)C_{d}, and the best split determined using O​(c​d​b)𝑂𝑐𝑑𝑏O(cdb) statistics, i.e., O​(c​d​b)​Cs+O​(d​b)​Cc𝑂𝑐𝑑𝑏subscript𝐶𝑠𝑂𝑑𝑏subscript𝐶𝑐O(cdb)C_{s}+O(db)C_{c}, where d​b𝑑𝑏db is the number of total splits; and (iii) model update step: the update of encrypted mask vectors, i.e., O​(n)​Ce𝑂𝑛subscript𝐶𝑒O(n)C_{e}. Thus, the total cost is O​(n​c​d¯​b​t)​Ce+O​(c​d​b​t)​(Cd+Cs)+O​(d​b​t)​Cc𝑂𝑛𝑐¯𝑑𝑏𝑡subscript𝐶𝑒𝑂𝑐𝑑𝑏𝑡subscript𝐶𝑑subscript𝐶𝑠𝑂𝑑𝑏𝑡subscript𝐶𝑐O(nc\bar{d}{b}t)C_{e}+O(c{d}bt)(C_{d}+C_{s})+O(dbt)C_{c}, where t𝑡t is the number of internal nodes in the tree model. With the enhanced protocol, the only difference is the two additional computations in the model update step: private split selection on b𝑏{b} split indicator vectors, i.e., O​(n​b)​Ce𝑂𝑛𝑏subscript𝐶𝑒O(n{b})C_{e}, and encrypted mask vector update that mainly requires n𝑛n threshold decryption operations, i.e., O​(n)​Cd𝑂𝑛subscript𝐶𝑑O(n)C_{d}. Thus, the total cost is O​(n​c​d¯​b​t)​Ce+O​(c​d​b​t+n​t)​Cd+O​(c​d​b​t)​Cs+O​(d​b​t)​Cc𝑂𝑛𝑐¯𝑑𝑏𝑡subscript𝐶𝑒𝑂𝑐𝑑𝑏𝑡𝑛𝑡subscript𝐶𝑑𝑂𝑐𝑑𝑏𝑡subscript𝐶𝑠𝑂𝑑𝑏𝑡subscript𝐶𝑐O(nc\bar{d}{b}t)C_{e}+O(c{d}bt+nt)C_{d}+O(cd{b}t)C_{s}+O(dbt)C_{c}.

Model prediction. With the basic protocol, the computational cost of prediction is updating an encrypted prediction vector with size (t+1)𝑡1(t+1) in a Robin round, i.e., O​(m​t)​Ce𝑂𝑚𝑡subscript𝐶𝑒O(mt)C_{e}, the homomorphic dot product between the encrypted prediction vector and the plaintext label vector, i.e., O​(t)​Ce𝑂𝑡subscript𝐶𝑒O(t)C_{e}, and the threshold decryption of the final prediction output, i.e., O​(1)​Cd𝑂1subscript𝐶𝑑O(1)C_{d}. Thus, the total cost is O​(m​t)​Ce+O​(1)​Cd𝑂𝑚𝑡subscript𝐶𝑒𝑂1subscript𝐶𝑑O(mt)C_{e}+O(1)C_{d}. With the enhanced protocol, the computational cost includes the secure comparison of t𝑡t internal nodes and the secure dot product between the prediction vector and the label vector, i.e., O​(t)​(Cs+Cc)𝑂𝑡subscript𝐶𝑠subscript𝐶𝑐O(t)(C_{s}+C_{c}).

In summary, regarding model training, the computational cost of the enhanced protocol is always larger than that of the basic protocol because the two additional computations are extra costs. Regarding model prediction, whether the basic protocol is better depends on the number of clients m𝑚m and the relationship between ciphertext computation cost and secure computation cost. We will experimentally evaluate the two protocols in Section 8.

7 Extensions to OTHER ML MODELS

So far, Pivot supports a single tree model. Now we briefly present how to extend the basic protocol to ensemble tree models, including random forest (RF) [12] and gradient boosting decision tree (GBDT) [35, 36] in Section 7.1 and Section 7.2, respectively. Same as the basic protocol, we assume that all the trees can be released in plaintext. The extension to other machine learning models is discussed in Section 7.3.

7.1 Random Forest

RF constructs a set of independent decision trees in the training stage and outputs the class that is the mode of the classes (for classification) or mean prediction (for regression) of those trees in the prediction stage.

For model training, the extension from a single decision tree is natural since each tree can be built (using Algorithm 3) and released separately. For model prediction, after obtaining the encrypted predicted label of each tree, the clients can easily convert these encrypted labels into secret shares for majority voting using secure maximum computation (for classification) or compute the encrypted mean prediction by homomorphic computations (for regression).

7.2 Gradient Boosting Decision Trees

GBDT uses decision trees as weak learners and improves model quality with a boosting strategy [34]. The trees are built sequentially where the training labels for the next tree are the prediction losses between the ground truth labels and the prediction outputs of previous trees.

Model training. The extension to GBDT is non-trivial, since we need to prevent the super client from knowing the training labels of each tree except the first tree (i.e., intermediate information) while facilitating the training process.

We first consider GBDT regression. Let W𝑊W be the number of rounds and a regression tree is built in each round. Let Ywsuperscript𝑌𝑤{Y}^{w} be the training label vector of the w𝑤w-th tree. We aim to protect Ywsuperscript𝑌𝑤{Y}^{w} by keeping it in an encrypted form. After building the w𝑤w-th tree where w∈{1,⋯,W−1}𝑤1⋯𝑊1w\in\{1,\cdots,W-1\}, the clients jointly make predictions for all training samples to get an encrypted estimation vector [Y¯w]delimited-[]superscript¯𝑌𝑤[\bar{{Y}}^{w}]; then the clients can compute the encrypted training labels [Yw+1]delimited-[]superscript𝑌𝑤1[{Y}^{w+1}] of the (w+1)𝑤1(w+1)-th tree given [Yw]delimited-[]superscript𝑌𝑤[{Y}^{w}] and [Y¯w]delimited-[]superscript¯𝑌𝑤[\bar{{Y}}^{w}]. Besides, note that in Section 4.2, an encrypted label square vector [𝜸2w+1]delimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝜸2𝑤1[\boldsymbol{\gamma}_{2}^{w+1}] is needed, which is computed by element-wise homomorphic multiplication between 𝜷2w+1superscriptsubscript𝜷2𝑤1\boldsymbol{\beta}_{2}^{w+1} and [𝜶]delimited-[]𝜶[\boldsymbol{\alpha}]. However, 𝜷2w+1superscriptsubscript𝜷2𝑤1\boldsymbol{\beta}_{2}^{w+1} is not plaintext here since the training labels are ciphertexts. Thus, the clients need expensive element-wise ciphertext multiplications (see Section 5.2) between [𝜷2w+1]delimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝜷2𝑤1[\boldsymbol{\beta}_{2}^{w+1}] and [𝜶]delimited-[]𝜶[\boldsymbol{\alpha}] in each iteration. To optimize this computation, we slightly modify our basic protocol. Instead of letting the super client compute [𝜸2w+1]delimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝜸2𝑤1[\boldsymbol{\gamma}_{2}^{w+1}] in each iteration, we now let the client who has the best split update [𝜸2w+1]delimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝜸2𝑤1[\boldsymbol{\gamma}_{2}^{w+1}] along with [𝜶]delimited-[]𝜶[\boldsymbol{\alpha}] using the same split indicator vector and broadcast them to all clients. In this way, the clients only need to compute [𝜸2w+1]delimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝜸2𝑤1[{\boldsymbol{\gamma}}_{2}^{w+1}] using [𝜷2w+1]delimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝜷2𝑤1[\boldsymbol{\beta}_{2}^{w+1}] and [𝜶]delimited-[]𝜶[\boldsymbol{\alpha}] once at the beginning of each round, which reduces the cost.

For GBDT classification, we use the one-vs-the-rest technique by combining a set of binary classifiers. Essentially, the clients need to build a GBDT regression forest for each class, resulting in W∗c𝑊𝑐W*c regression trees in total (c𝑐c is the number of classes). After each round in the training stage, the clients obtain c𝑐c trees; and for each training sample, the clients make a prediction on each tree, resulting in c𝑐c encrypted prediction outputs. Then, the clients jointly convert them into secretly shared values for computing secure softmax (which can be constructed using secure exponential, secure addition, and secure division, as mentioned in Section 2.2), and convert them back into an encrypted form as encrypted estimations. The rest of the computation is the same as regression.

Model prediction. For GBDT regression, the prediction output can be decrypted after homomorphic aggregating the encrypted predictions of all trees. For GBDT classification, the encrypted prediction for each class is the same as that for regression; then the clients jointly convert these encrypted results into secretly shared values for deciding the final prediction output by secure softmax function.

7.3 Other Machine Learning Models

Though we consider tree-based models in this paper, the proposed solution can be easily adopted in other vertical FL models, such as logistic regression (LR), neural networks, and so on. The rationale is that these models can often be partitioned into the three steps described in Section 4.1. As a result, the TPHE primitives, conversion algorithm, and secure computation operators can be re-used.

For example, the clients can train a vertical LR model as follows. To protect the intermediate weights of the LR model during the training, the clients initialize an encrypted weight vector, [𝜽]=([𝜽1],⋯,[𝜽m])delimited-[]𝜽delimited-[]subscript𝜽1⋯delimited-[]subscript𝜽𝑚[\boldsymbol{\theta}]=([\boldsymbol{\theta}_{1}],\cdots,[\boldsymbol{\theta}_{m}]), where [𝜽i]delimited-[]subscript𝜽𝑖[\boldsymbol{\theta}_{i}] corresponds to the encrypted weights of features held by client i𝑖i. In each iteration, for a Sample t𝑡t, each client i𝑖i first locally aggregates an encrypted partial sum, say [ξi​t]delimited-[]subscript𝜉𝑖𝑡[\xi_{it}], by homomorphic dot product between [𝜽i]delimited-[]subscript𝜽𝑖[\boldsymbol{\theta}_{i}] and Sample t𝑡t’s local features xi​tsubscriptx𝑖𝑡\textbf{x}_{it}. Then the clients jointly convert {[ξi​t]}i=1msuperscriptsubscriptdelimited-[]subscript𝜉𝑖𝑡𝑖1𝑚\{[\xi_{it}]\}_{i=1}^{m} into secretly shared values using Algorithm 2, and securely aggregate them before computing the secure logistic function. Meanwhile, the super client also provides Sample t𝑡t’s label as a secretly shared value, such that the clients can jointly compute the secretly shared loss of Sample t𝑡t. After that, the clients convert the loss back into the encrypted form (see Section 5.2), and each client can update her encrypted weights [𝜽i]delimited-[]subscript𝜽𝑖[\boldsymbol{\theta}_{i}] using homomorphic properties, without knowing the loss. Besides, the model prediction is a half component of one iteration in training, which can be easily computed.

8 Experiments

We evaluate the performance of Pivot basic protocol (Section 4) and Pivot enhanced protocol (Section 5) on the decision tree model, as well as the ensemble extensions (Section 7). We present the accuracy evaluation in Section 8.2 and the efficiency evaluation in Section 8.3.

We implement Pivot in C++ and employ the GMP222http://gmplib.org library for big integer computation and the libhcs333https://github.com/tiehuis/libhcs library for operations of the threshold Paillier scheme. We utilize the SPDZ444https://github.com/data61/MP-SPDZ library for semi-honest additive secret sharing computations. Besides, we apply the libscapi555https://github.com/cryptobiu/libscapi library to provide network communications among clients. Since the cryptographic primitives only support big integer computations, we convert the floating point datasets into fixed-point integer representation.

8.1 Experimental Setup

We conduct experiments on a cluster of machines in a local area network (LAN). Each machine is equipped with Intel (R) Xeon (R) CPU E5-1650 v3 @ 3.50GHz×\times12 and 32GB of RAM, running Ubuntu 16.04 LTS. Unless noted otherwise, the keysize of threshold Paillier scheme is 1024 bits and the security parameter of SPDZ configuration is 128 bits.

Datasets. We evaluate the model accuracy using three real-world datasets: credit card data (30000 samples with 25 features) [79], bank marketing data (4521 samples with 17 features) [58], and appliances energy prediction data (19735 samples with 29 features) [14]. The former two datasets are for classification while the third dataset is for regression.

We evaluate the efficiency using synthetic datasets, which are generated with sklearn666https://scikit-learn.org/stable/ library. Specifically, we vary the number of samples (n𝑛n) and the number of total features (d𝑑d) to generate datasets and then equally split these datasets w.r.t. features into m𝑚m partitions, which are held by m𝑚m clients, respectively. We denote d¯=d/m¯𝑑𝑑𝑚\bar{d}=d/m as the number of features each client holds. For classification tasks, the number of classes is set to 4, and only one client holds the labels.

Baselines. For accuracy evaluation, we adopt the non-private decision tree (NP-DT), non-private random forest (NP-RF), and non-private gradient-boosting decision tree (NP-GBDT) algorithms from sklearn for comparison. For a fair comparison, we adopt the same hyper-parameters for both our protocols and the baselines, e.g., the maximum tree depth, the pruning conditions, the number of trees, etc.

For efficiency evaluation, to our knowledge, there is no existing work providing the same privacy guarantee as Pivot. Therefore, we implement a secret sharing based decision tree algorithm using the SPDZ library (namely, SPDZ-DT) as a baseline. The security parameter of SPDZ-DT is also 128 bits. Besides, we also implement a non-private distributed decision tree (NPD-DT) algorithm as another baseline to illustrate the overhead of protecting the data privacy. In NPD-DT, the super client broadcasts plaintext labels to all clients, each client computes split statistics and exchanges them in plaintext with others to decide the best split.

Metrics. For model accuracy, we measure the number of samples that are correctly classified over the total testing samples for classification; and the mean square error (MSE) between the predicted labels and the ground truth labels for regression. For efficiency, we measure the total running time of the model training stage and the prediction running time per sample of the model prediction stage. In all experiments, we report the running time of the online phase because SPDZ did not support the offline time benchmark for the semi-honest additive secret sharing protocol.

8.2 Evaluation of Accuracy

In terms of accuracy, we compare the performance of the proposed decision tree (Pivot-DT), random forest (Pivot-RF) and gradient boosting decision tree (Pivot-GBDT) algorithms with their non-private baselines on three real world datasets. In these experiments, the keysize of threshold Paillier scheme is set to 512 bits. We conduct 10 independent trials of each experiment and report the average result.

Table 3 summarizes the comparison results. We can notice that the Pivot algorithms achieve accuracy comparable to the non-private baselines. There are two reasons for the slight loss of accuracy. First, we use the fixed-point integer to represent float values, whose precision is thus truncated. Second, Pivot has only implemented the basic algorithms, which are not optimized as the adopted baselines.

8.3 Evaluation for Efficiency
